Anna Ternheim, a Swedish pop star known for her structured performances, found a new creative home in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. While her seventh album is titled *"All the Way to Rio"*—a nod to both her origins and the vibrant city that inspired her—Anna’s work isn’t defined by exoticism. Instead, the album emerges from her quest for refuge amid shifting landscapes.

**Creative Catalysts:**
- **Contrast between Environments:** In Sweden, Anna thrived under familiarity, crafting pop hits. In Rio, the organic, unstructured environment offered freedom. She channeled this dichotomy into her music, blending REM-influenced pastoral guitars and fuzz-laden organ to craft tracks like *"Hold On"* and the ethereal *"Battered Soul."* The album’s title track becomes a metaphor: "We ran from our friends / Saying they’re all the same," reflecting her escape from quotidian norms into Rio’s wilder embrace.

The HCMF really hit its stride in the early 80s, hosting a series of important premieres alongside residencies from many of the senior figures of postwar music, from Olivier Messiaen and Terry Riley to Hans Werner Henze and Elliott Carter. Gradually expanding its ambition and range, Steinitz’s programming was never narrowly doctrinal; from the early days, he tried to reflect the spectrum of what was going on across Europe and the US. The current director, Graham McKenzie, has been there for more than a decade, not only steering the programming towards new generations of composers from across Europe, but also broadening the stylistic scope, including events that touch on jazz, electronica and rock. With these changes, so the atmosphere of the festival has altered. This is partly because the generation of postwar composers whose appearances made the early festivals so memorable has all but gone, but also because, in those days, festival audiences had a sense of a shared purpose.
